document.docAuthor: Nobre, Welington B. & Ruiz, Gustavo R.S.
document.docTitle: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the boundary of the jumping spider genus Rhyphelia Simon, 1902 (Araneae: Salticidae: Euophryini), with description of ten new species

emphasis.docTitle:
On the boundary of the jumping spider genus
Rhyphelia Simon, 1902
( Araneae : Salticidae : Euophryini), with description of ten new species

subSection.paragraph: WELINGTON B. NOBRE 1 & GUSTAVO R.S. RUIZ 2*

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Programa de Pós-Graduação em Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Pará / Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Brazil
Instituto de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Federal do Pará, Rua Augusto Corrêa, 01, CEP 66075-110, Belém, PA , Brazil

subSection.paragraph:
In this paper we synonymize
Soesilarishius Makhan, 2007
with
Rhyphelia Simon, 1902
. We give new illustrations of the male holotype of the type species
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
for comparisons, and describe the closely related
Rhyphelia brevistylus
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from the state of Bahia, Brazil . Additionally, we describe nine other new species from different Brazilian regions:
Rhyphelia barbado
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Bahia ,
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Minas Gerais ,
Rhyphelia cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Mato Grosso ,
Rhyphelia gallina
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Acre ,
Rhyphelia novalima
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) and
Rhyphelia okay
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Minas Gerais ,
Rhyphelia otti
sp. nov.
( ♂ ♀ ) from Rio Grande do Sul ,
Rhyphelia planaria
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from São Paulo , and
Rhyphelia tocantinensis
sp. nov.
( ♂ ) from Tocantins .

Key words:
Brazil
, Salticinae ,
Soesilarishius
,
new synonym , new combination
, taxonomy

Euophryini Simon, 1901 is the largest tribe of jumping spiders, with more than 1000 described species (around 15% of the salticid species described) distributed in various terrestrial ecosystems around the world ( Maddison 2015 ; World Spider Catalog 2023 ). Prószyński (1976) contributed to delimiting the group, based mainly on the embolus form. Maddison & Hedin (2003) , based on phylogenetic analyses using molecular data, compiled a list with 34 genera. Later, Zhang & Maddison (2013) , also using molecular data, showed that many lineages with different embolus also belonged in the group (including
Soesilarishius Makhan, 2007
and
Popcornella Zhang & Maddison, 2012
), increasing the number of genera up to 85. A more recent phylogenetic study ( Zhang & Maddison 2015 ) combined molecular and morphological data, and increased the genus list of the tribe up to 108 genera (including
Rhyphelia Simon, 1902
, based on similarities with
Soesilarishius
). The tribe currently includes more than 130 genera (
Yu et al. 2023
).

Euophryini is still mainly defined by the morphology of the male palp, with a spiraled embolus restricted to the most distal portion of the bulb, with the plane of the spiral almost parallel to the longitudinal axis of the palp and with a retrolateral loop of the spermophore (RSDL) towards the central area of the tegulum ( Zhang & Maddison 2013 : fig. 4A). Although this pattern of male palp is present in almost all genera of the tribe, others have different embolus and may have lost the spermophore loop ( Zhang & Maddison 2013 : fig. 4G). Females of Euophryini usually have a pair of large areas covered with a thin cuticle on the epigyne, called the “windows”, through which it is possible to visualize the spermathecae located inside the body ( Zhang & Maddison 2013 : figs 4B, 4J). However, the windows may also be absent in some groups (see Zhang & Maddison 2013 : figs 4D, 4H), including in many related Neotropical lineages ( Zhang & Maddison 2013 , 2015 ), such as
Soesilarishius
,
Rhyphelia
,
Marma Simon, 1902
(see Salgado & Ruiz 2020 : figs 6C, 7G, 7H),
Amphidraus Simon, 1900
(see Salgado & Ruiz 2019 : figs 4C, 5F) and
Neonella Gertsch, 1936
(see Salgado & Ruiz 2018 : figs 4F, 4G). Most of these absences/reductions, however, may be homoplasies, since the epigynal windows are present in other related genera in the same clade, such as
Coryphasia Simon, 1902
and
Ilargus Simon, 1901
( Zhang & Maddison 2015 ).

The genus
Soesilarishius
was proposed by Makhan (2007) with only the type species
S. amrishi Makhan, 2007
described from a male specimen collected in Suriname . Ruiz (2011) gathered a group of seven species as belonging in the genus and transferred
Euophrys aurifrons Taczanowski, 1878
to
Soesilarishius
. Since then, other species have been described in the genus ( Zhang & Maddison 2012a ; Ruiz 2013 ; Ruiz & Sobrinho 2016 ). Ruiz & Sobrinho (2016) also redescribed the male and described the previously unknown female of the type species. Hitherto, the genus is composed of 23 species, 17 of which have been described with both male and female, and six only with male ( World Spider Catalog 2023 ). Spiders of
Soesilarishius
are found in different biomes of South America, usually on the ground in vegetation-covered areas ( Ruiz 2013 ), where a high layer of litter is accumulated.Although corroborated with molecular data as a true Euophryini ( Zhang & Maddison 2013 , 2015 ), this genus does not have the typical spiraled embolus of the tribe. Instead, species of
Soesilarishius
exhibit great diversity in the morphology of the male palps and epigynes (e.g. Ruiz 2011 , 2013 ).

Rhyphelia
, on the other hand, is a poorly known monotypic genus. The type species
R. variegata Simon, 1902
(only the male is known) was redescribed by Galiano (1963) , and the genus was considered probably closely related to
Soesilarishius
due to the similar morphology of the male palp ( Zhang & Maddison 2015: 25 ).

Considering the morphological diversity present in the lineage, we herein synonymize
Rhyphelia
and
Soesilarishius
based on their similar body form and genitalic structures. In addition, ten new species are described, which furtherering the morphological diversity present in the lineage, increase the species diversity of this group.

The material belongs to the Museu de Ciências Naturais, Fundação Zoobotânica do Rio Grande do Sul (MCN/ FZBRS; curator: R. Ott); Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG; curator: A. Bonaldo); Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG; curator: A. Santos); and the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris (MNHN; curator: C. Rollard).
Geographic coordinates are expressed in decimal degrees and were taken directly from labels.

The order of species descriptions is given to maximize comparisons between similar species across the manuscript, as follows: the type species of
Rhyphelia
, followed by the striking similar
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
, followed by the
R. barbado
sp. nov.
/
R. otti
sp. nov.
pair, which should be preferably compared side by side, the unusual
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
, followed by the
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
/
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
and the
R. gallina
sp. nov.
/
R. planaria
sp. nov.
pairs, which should be preferably compared side by side, followed by
R. novalima
sp. nov.
and
R. okay
sp. nov.

bibRefCitation.refString: Simon, E. (1902) Description d'arachnides nouveaux de la famille des Salticidae (Attidae) (suite). Annales de la Societe Entomologique de Belgique, 46, 24 - 56 + 363 - 406.

subSubSection.paragraph:
( Type species:
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
, by original designation); World Spider Catalog 2023 .

bibRefCitation.author: Makhan, D.
bibRefCitation.refString: Makhan, D. (2007) Soesiladeepakius aschnae gen. et sp. nov. and Soesilarishius amrishi gen. et sp. nov. from Suriname (Araneae: Salticidae). Calodema Supplementary Paper, 60, 1 - 8.

subSubSection.paragraph:
( Type species:
Soesilarishius amrishi Makhan, 2007
, by original designation); World Spider Catalog 2023 — NEW SYNONYMY .

Diagnosis. Species included in this genus are small, brownish South American litter or trunk dwelling euophryines with reduced spiraled emboli (for further notes, see Galiano 1963 ; Ruiz 2011 , 2013 ; Zhang & Maddison 2015 ; Ruiz & Sobrinho 2016 ). In that sense,
Rhyphelia
resembles the unrelated
Popcornella
from the Caribbean islands, but
Popcornella
has a short retrolateral tibial apophysis in the male palp (larger in
Rhyphelia
) and shortened copulatory ducts in the epigyne (longer in
Rhyphelia
) (See Zhang & Maddison, 2012b : figs 219–223).

Phylogenetic position. According to Zhang & Maddison (2015) , this group (included as “
Soesilarishius
” in the analyses) was found as part of a Neotropical clade gathering other genera, such as
Amphidraus
,
Marma
,
Tylogonus Simon, 1902
,
Mopiopia Simon, 1902
,
Saphrys Zhang & Maddison, 2015
,
Coryphasia
,
Neonella
,
Ecuadattus Zhang & Maddison, 2012
and
Ilargus
. The similar morphology present in some
Rhyphelia
and in
Popcornella
(body size, coloration, reduced structures in male palp and epigyne) represent, hence, convergences, since these genera are not closely related (see Zhang & Maddison 2015 ).

Note. Males of two species (
R. variegata
and
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
) have projected endites ( Fig. 1B ) and developed tegular lobe, both absent or reduced in the remaining species of the genus. However, these structures are extremely variable in Euophryini and were considered not enough to predict the independence of both genera, given the diversity of the lineage. Unpublished DNA sequences of an undescribed species from Ecuador closely related to the type species,
R. variegata
, places the Ecuadorian species with the remaining species of the lineage sampled in molecular studies (
R. amrishi
,
R. micacea
and
R. ruizi
; see species authors below) (W. Maddison, pers. comm). Despite several species already being described, analyses of Brazilian collections show that this lineage is one of the largest ground-dwelling spider groups in South America in terms of species number, with many more species awaiting formal description. Given the similarities, the large number of genera in the tribe, the close relationship between type species demonstrated with DNA sequences and, most importantly, to ensure taxonomic stability, we decided to synonymize the two genera herein.

subSubSection.paragraph:
34.
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
(see comments below)

bibRefCitation.author: Simon, E.
bibRefCitation.refString: Simon, E. (1902) Description d'arachnides nouveaux de la famille des Salticidae (Attidae) (suite). Annales de la Societe Entomologique de Belgique, 46, 24 - 56 + 363 - 406.

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 1. Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902, male holotype. A dorsal view; B chelicera and endites, ventral view; C–D right male palp, digitally inverted (C ventral view; D retrolateral view).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The male of
R. variegata
is similar to that of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
by the longer carapace (about 1.5x longer than wide, Figs 1A , 2A ; shorter, 1.3–1.4x longer than wide in the remaining species), by the developed tegular lobe ( Figs 1C , 3A ) and by the spurs on the border of the endites ( Fig. 1B ). The male of
R. variegata
differs from that of
R. brevistylus
by the long embolus, which reaches almost the length of the tegulum ( Fig. 1C ) (about one third the length of tegulum in
R. brevistylus
; Fig. 3A ). The female is unknown.
Redescription. See Galiano (1963) . Herein we give new illustrations of the holotype for comparison ( Figs 1A–D ).

Distribution. The original description mentions Caracas ( Venezuela ) as the type locality, but the label states the actual type locality in the state of Rio de Janeiro , Brazil ( Galiano 1963 ) ( Fig. 22 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Rhyphelia variegata Simon, 1902
, male holotype. A dorsal view; B chelicera and endites, ventral view; C–D right male palp, digitally inverted (C ventral view; D retrolateral view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 2A–2D , 3A–3C , 4A–4F

Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata da Tijuquinha , Serra do Barbado , Distrito de Catolés , Abaíra , Bahia , Brazil ( 13.269°S , 41.911°W ),
1.XI.2013
, L.S Carvalho & M.B da Silva leg. (UFMG 14990)
.
Paratypes :
1♂ 1♀ , from Parque Estadual da Serra do Japi , Jundiaí , São Paulo , Brazil ( 23.283°S 46.983°W ),
3.XI.2007
, J. Sobjack leg. (UFMG 6478)
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Rhyphelia brevistylus
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view); C–D female (C dorsal view; D ventral view).

FIGURE 3.
Rhyphelia brevistylus
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype, left palp (A ventral view; B retrolateral view); C epigyne, ventral view. D
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
epigyne, ventral view.

FIGURE 4.
Rhyphelia brevistylus
sp. nov.
A–C male holotype, left palp (A ventral view; B retrolateral view; C retro-dorsal view). D–F epigyne (D ventral view; E same, cleared; F dorsal view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a compound noun in apposition, is a combination of Latin adjective “brevis” (short) and noun “stylus” (embolus).

Diagnosis. The male of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
is similar to that of
R. variegata
by the longer carapace (about 1.5x longer than wide, Figs 1A , 2A ; shorter, 1.3–1.4x longer than wide in the remaining species), by the developed tegular lobe ( Figs 1C , 3A ) and by the spurs on the border of the endites. The male of
R. brevistylus
sp. nov.
differs from that of
R. variegata
by the shorter embolus, which reaches about one third the length of tegulum ( Fig. 3A ) (almost the length of the tegulum in
R. variegata
; Fig. 1C ). The female differs from all the other species of the genus by having copulatory openings facing ectally, followed by anterior ducts with large secondary spermathecae ( Figs 3C , 4D–F ).

Female paratype .
Total length: 3.67. Carapace as in male ( Fig. 2C ); 1.63 long, 1.05 wide, 0.65 high. Ocular quadrangle 0.72; anterior eye row 0.96, posterior 0.91 wide. Chelicera, labium, endite, sternum and palp brown. Leg formula: 4312; length of legs: I 2.32 (0.72 + 0.45 + 0.50 + 0.36 + 0.29), II 2.10 (0.62 + 0.38 + 0.48 + 0.33 + 0.29), III 2.56 (0.72 + 0.38 + 0.50 + 0.60 + 0.36), IV 2.98 (0.84 + 0.41 + 0.72 + 0.65 + 0.36). Legs coloration: femora, patellae, tibiae, metatarsi and tarsi proximally dark brown and distally yellow. Macrosetae as in male. Abdomen as in male ( Figs 2C–D ). Epigyne with posterior median coupling pocket; crescent-shaped copulatory openings facing ectally; copulatory ducts running anteriorly, then curve dorsally and flip back posteriorly; secondary spermathecae anteriorly on ducts right after dorsal folding; spermathecae round ( Figs 3C , 4D–F ). Spinnerets yellow.
Distribution. Known only from the states of Bahia and São Paulo , Brazil ( Fig. 23 ).
Figs 5A–5D , 7A–7B

materialsCitation.collectorName: L. S. Carvalho & M. B. da Silva

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Mata da Tijuquinha , Serra do Barbado , Distrito de Catolés , Abaíra , Bahia , Brazil ( 13.269°S , 41.911°W ),
1.XI.2013
, L.S. Carvalho & M.B. da Silva leg. (UFMG 14979).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Epithet, a noun in apposition, is taken from type locality.

Diagnosis. Among the species of the genus, the male of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
is most similar to that of
R. otti
sp. nov.
, as it has an elongated and flattened embolus, almost parallel to the longitudinal axis, with a fold at the most apical region (compare Figs 7A, 7C ). The male of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
can be distinguished by the membranous lamella on the prolateral side of the embolus ( Fig. 7A ; smooth embolus in
S. otti
sp. nov.
, Fig. 7C ).
Female. Unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Bahia , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).
Figs 5E–5F , 6A–6D , 7C–7G

Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from
Centro de Pesquisas
e Conservação da Natureza Pró-Mata , São Francisco de Paula , Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil ,
02.I.2001
, R. Ott leg. (MCN/FZBRS-39661)
.
Paratype :
1♀ , same data as holotype (MCN/FZBRS-39661)
.
Etymology. Epithet is in honour of the Brazilian arachnologist Ricardo Ott, who collected the type specimens.

Diagnosis. Among the species of the genus, the male of
R. otti
sp. nov.
is most similar to that of
R. barbado
sp. nov.
, as it has an elongated and flattened embolus, almost parallel to the longitudinal axis, with a fold at the most apical region (compare Figs 7A, 7C ). The male of
R. otti
sp. nov.
can be distinguished by the smooth embolus axis ( Fig. 7C ; embolus bearing a membranous lamella on the prolateral side in
S. barbado
sp. nov.
, Fig. 7A ). Among the species with known females,
R. otti
sp. nov.
is most similar to
R. ruizi ( Zhang & Maddison, 2015 )
comb. nov.
, given their narrow, inverted V-shaped coupling pocket, but it can be distinguished by the longer loop in the middle portion of the copulatory duct ( Fig. 7F ; smaller loop in
R. ruizi
, see Zhang & Maddison 2015 : figs 279–280).

FIGURE 5.
Rhyphelia spp. A
–B
Rhyphelia barbado
sp. nov.
holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view), C–D male holotype, right palp, digitally inverted horizontally to mimic left palp (C ventral view; D retrolateral view). E–F
Rhyphelia otti
sp. nov.
male holotype, left palp (E ventral view; F retrolateral view).

FIGURE 6.
Rhyphelia otti
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view); C–D female paratype (C dorsal view; D ventral view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Rhyphelia spp. A
–B
Rhyphelia barbado
sp. nov.
male holotype, right palp, inverted (A ventral view; B retrolateral view). C–G
Rhyphelia otti
sp. nov.
C–D male holotype, left palp (C ventral view; D retrolateral view). E–G epigyne (E ventral view; F same, cleared; G dorsal view).

FIGURE 8.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view); C–D female (C dorsal view; D ventral view). Arrow in B shows cluster of modified setae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype :
♂ from Mata Samuel de Paula , Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural , Nova Lima , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 20°S , 43.867°W ),
12–18.X.2006
, J.P.P. Pena-Barbosa et al. leg. ( UFMG 2933 )
.
Paratypes :
1♂ 1♀ , female from Estação Ecológica da Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais , Belo Horizinte , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 19.874°S 43.972°W ),
IX.2000
, unknown coll. (UFMG 8298)
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
A–C male holotype, left palp (A prolateral view; B ventral view; C retrolateral view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, is due to two bands of white stripes present dorsally, extending from the anterior region of the cephalic area to the end of the abdomen.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. crispiventer ( Ruiz, 2011 )
comb. nov.
and
R. excentrica ( Ruiz, 2013 )
comb. nov.
by the long embolus coiled clockwise (left palp; in most species with long embolus, the embolus coils anti-clockwise). As in
R. crispiventer
, the base of the embolus is hidden distally under the rounded tegulum (dislocated prolaterally in
R. excentrica
), but the embolus is longer in
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
( Figs 10A–10C ) when comparing to
R. crispiventer
(see Ruiz 2011 : figs 10–12). Those three species share a cluster of modified bristles ventrally on the posterior region of the abdomen ( Figs 8B , 12 ).
R. bilineata
sp. nov.
is also easily distinguished from other species by having a pair of bands of white scale on the dorsum of the carapace and abdomen (in both male and female). The female differs from those of other species by having a complete loop in the initial portion of copulatory duct ( Fig. 10E ).

Description. Male holotype .
Total length: 1.94. Carapace dark brown; cephalic region black ( Fig. 8A ); 0.98 long, 0.67 wide, 0.42 high. Ocular quadrangle 0.44; anterior eye row 0.71, posterior 0.67 wide. Chelicera, labium, endite, sternum and palp cream-colored ( Fig. 8B ). RTA long ( Fig. 10C ). Leg formula: 3412; length of legs: I 1.32 (0.44 + 0.19 + 0.29 + 0.21 + 0.19), II 1.10 (0.34 + 0.15 + 0.23 + 0.21 + 0.17), III 1.65 (0.57 + 0.23 + 0.32 + 0.34 + 0.19), IV 1.63 (0.51 + 0.19 + 0.32 + 0.38 + 0.23). Legs cream-colored. Tibia I macrosetae not well developed. Abdomen dorsally dark brown ( Fig. 8A ); ventrally cream-colored ( Fig. 8B ). Spinnerets cream-colored. Anterior lateral spinneret with one major ampullate spigot ( Fig. 11C : smaller red arrows) and three or four piriform spigots ( Fig. 11C : yellow arrows); posterior median spinneret apparently with only one minor ampullate spigot ( Fig. 11C : larger red arrows); posterior lateral spigot with a pair of aciniform spigots ( Fig. 11C : green arrows).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov .
A–C male holotype, left palp (A prolateral view; B ventral view; C retrolateral view). D–F epigyne (D ventral view; E same, cleared; F dorsal view).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Female paratype .
Total Length: 2.28. Carapace as in male ( Fig. 8C ); 1.07 long, 0.75 wide, 0.52 high. Ocular quadrangle 0.57; anterior eye row 0.79, posterior 0.67 wide. Chelicera, labium, endite, sternum and palp yellow ( Fig. 8D ). Leg formula: 4312; length of legs: I 1.65 (0.52 + 0.27 + 0.38 + 0.27 + 0.21), II 1.45 (0.46 + 0.25 + 0.30 + 0.23 + 0.21), III 1.73 (0.57 + 0.27 + 0.36 + 0.32 + 0.21), IV 1.89 (0.57 + 0.23 + 0.42 + 0.42 + 0.25). Legs yellow. Macrosetae as in male. Abdomen as in male, without modified ventral bristles. Epigyne with crescent-shaped copulatory openings facing each other, long ducts and elliptical spermathecae ( Figs 3D , 10D–10F ). Spinnerets cream-colored.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
A–B male, dorsal view; C spinnerets [red arrows: major (anterior lateral spinneret) and minor (posterior median spinneret) ampullate gland spigots; yellow arrows: piriform gland spigots; green arrows: aciniform gland spigots). D left male palp, prolateral view. Arrow shows the paraembolic apophysis.

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 13A–13B , 14A–14D

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Fazenda São Nicolau , Cotriguaçu , Mato Grosso , Brazil ( 9.840°S , 58.248°W ),
2–14.X.2010
, A.J. Santos leg. (UFMG 7696).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, refers to the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov .
is similar to those
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi
by having a short and wide embolus, projecting from the prolateral region of the tegulum and covered by a membranous layer ( Fig. 14C ), but differs by the more cylindrical shape of the embolus with a small apophysis at the apical region, as well as a simple and curved RTA directed towards the posterior region of the bulb ( Fig. 14D ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
, males, ventral view. A and C male 1; B and D male 2.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female. Unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Mato Grosso , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).

Rhyphelia spp. A
–B
Rhyphelia cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
, male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view). C–D
Rhyphelia tocantinensis
sp. nov.
, male holotype (C dorsal view; D ventral view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 13C–13D , 14E–14H

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural Canguçu , Centro de Pesquisa Canguçu , Pium , Tocantins , Brazil ( 9.977°S 50.085°W ),
18.V.2016
, leg. A.B. Bonaldo et al. (MPEG 39057).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a Latin adjective, was built based on the type locality.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14.
Rhyphelia spp. A
–D
Rhyphelia cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
male holotype, left palp (A and C ventral view; B and D retrolateral view). E–H
Rhyphelia tocantinensis
sp. nov.
male holotype, left palp (E and G ventral view; F and H retrolateral view).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The male of
R. tocantinensis
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. cotriguacuensis
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi (Zhang & Maddison, 2012)
comb. nov.
by having a short and wide embolus, projecting from the prolateral region of the tegulum and partially covered by a membranous layer ( Fig. 14G ), but differs from them by having an apical constriction in the embolus, and by a robust RTA directed toward the center of the tegulum ( Fig. 14H ).
Female. Unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Tocantins , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).
Figs 15A–15B , 16A–16D

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Campus Embrapa , Rio Branco , Acre , Brazil ( 10.025°S , 67.693°W ),
VIII.2012
, L.M.S. Costa leg. (UFMG 12402).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Epithet, a Latin noun in apposition, is due to the shape of the RTA, reminiscent of a chicken wing.

Diagnosis. The male is similar to that of
R. amrishi
by having a smooth embolus projecting from a sclerotized distal region and reaching the tip of the cymbium ( Fig. 16C ). However, it differs by having an elongate RTA curved towards the center of the tegulum ( Fig. 16D ; short in
R. amrishi
, see Ruiz & Sobrinho (2016 : fig. 6).
Female. Unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Acre , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).
Figs 15C–15D , 16E–16H

materialsCitation.collectorName: G. H. F. Azevedo & J. P. P. Pena-Barbosa

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Estação Ecológica de Jureia-Itatins (Núcleo Arpoador), Peruíbe , São Paulo , Brazil ( 24.387°S , 47.017°W ),
21–26.IV.2012
, G.H.F. Azevedo & J.P.P. Pena-Barbosa leg. (UFMG 13046).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Epithet, a noun in apposition, is due to the shape of the embolus tip, reminiscent of a typical planarian head.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. planaria
sp. nov.
is similar to those
R. otti
sp. nov.
and
R. barbado
sp. nov.
for having a thin embolus with an apical twist ( Fig. 16G ), but differs for being shorter.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 17.
Rhyphelia novalima
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view); C–D female (C dorsal view; D ventral view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, a noun in apposition, was taken from the type locality.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. novalima
sp. nov.
is similar to those of
R. tabernarius ( Ruiz, 2013 )
comb nov.
and
S. minima ( Ruiz, 2011 )
comb. nov.
by the spiraled embolus, but it differs from both by having a less compact spiral ( Fig. 19A ). The female differs from all other known species by having the copulatory openings facing ectally, towards the laterals of the abdomen, with the copulatory ducts running posteriorly ( Fig. 18C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18.
Rhyphelia spp. A
–C
Rhyphelia novalima
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype, left palp (A ventral view; B retrolateral view); C epigyne, ventral view. D–F
Rhyphelia okay
sp. nov.
D–E male holotype, left palp (D ventral view; E retrolateral view); F epigyne, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note. As stated, typical species of
Rhyphelia
do not have the typical spiraled embolus of Euophryini. However, the embolus of
R. novalima
sp. nov.
is reminiscent of the typical euophryine embolus. This feature is interpretated here as a reversion, since size, coloration and epigyne conformation are typical for the genus.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 19.
Rhyphelia novalima
sp. nov .
A–B male holotype, left palp (A ventral view; B retrolateral view); C–E epigyne (C ventral view; D same, cleared; E dorsal view).

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ from Pico do Sol , Santuário do Caraça , Reserva Particular do Patrimônio Natural , Santa Barbara , Minas Gerais , Brazil ( 20.059°S , 43.505°W ),
7.X.2010
, L.N Perillo leg. (UFMG 6606).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 20.
Rhyphelia okay
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype (A dorsal view; B ventral view); C–D female (C dorsal view; D ventral view).

FIGURE 21.
Rhyphelia okay
sp. nov.
A–B male holotype, left palp (A ventral view; B retrolateral view). C–E epigyne (C ventral view; D same, cleared; E dorsal view).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The epithet, to be treated as a noun in apposition, is due to the embolus and paraembolic apophysis reminiscent of the sign for “okay ” in LIBRAS, the Brazilian Sign Language.

Diagnosis. The male of
R. okay
sp. nov.
differs from all other known species of
Rhyphelia
by having an apophysis projecting from the base of the embolus towards the apex of the cymbium ( Fig. 21A ). The female is similar to those of
R. otti
sp. nov.
and
R. ruizi
for the narrow coupling pocket on the epigyne ( Fig. 21C ), but differs by the shorter copulatory ducts (loops close to spermathecae).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 22. Map with individual symbols for the species of
Rhyphelia
described and recorded prior to this work (new species described herein are mapped as red triangles and separate in the next map). Brazilian states are in italics.

FIGURE 23. Map with individual symbols for the new species of
Rhyphelia
described herein (species previously described and recorded are mapped as red triangles and were separate in the previous map). Brazilian states are in italics.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Minas Gerais , Brazil ) ( Fig. 23 ).

subSection.paragraph:
The genus
Rhyphelia
presents a great variation regarding palpal morphology, with at least three possible positions for the embolus base. The species
R. amrishi , R. albipes , R. chaplini , R. cymbialis , R. dromedarius , R. lunata , R. macrochelis , R. tabernarius , R. spinipes
,
R. variegata
and
R. brevistylus
have the embolus base distally on the bulb, while
R. bicrescens
,
R. cearensis , R. aurifrons , R. laticlavus , R. muiratinga , R. paxiuba , R. ruizi
, and
R. trombetas
have the embolus base in a more median region of the bulb, which is a possible intermediate among the three variations. The species
R. elongatula , R. flagelator
, and
R. micacea
have the embolus base in the most proximal region of the bulb, with a spiraled and elongate embolus. The varying embolus length (and base position), however, may represent only grades and no species group is based on that character so far. Once more species are described, and possibly unknown females of others, a more complete scenario can be established based on phylogenetic studies.

Despite these limitations in delimiting species groups based on embolus morphology, a group composed of three species can be formed based on well-evident morphological characters that distinguish them from the other described species.
Rhyphelia bilineata
sp. nov.
,
R. crispiventer
and
R. excentrica
have a long embolus that is coiled clockwise (left palp), unusual for the genus. In most other species with long embolus, the embolus coils anti-clockwise in the left palp, as in most Euophryini. Also, these three species seem to have a hooked apophysis near the embolus base (see Figs 10A , 11D ), and they share a cluster of modified bristles ventrally on the posterior region of the abdomen ( Figs 8B , 12 ). These setae are believed to have a stridulatory function during courtship and are well developed in males only.

We would also like to thank the Universidade Federal do Pará (UFPA), the Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG) and their Graduate Program in Zoology (PPGZOOL) for the facilities. To Adalberto Santos (UFMG), Élise-Anne Leguin and Christine Rollard (MNHN), and Ricardo Ott (MCN) for sending specimens. To Histon Costi and Laura Miglio for helping with SEM illustrations. Also, to Abel Bustamante for the constant support to WBN during the development of this work. Finally, to the members of the evaluation board (Dr Abel Antonio Bustamante Ferrada, Dr Antonio Domingos Brescovit, Dr Fernando Augusto Barbosa Silva and Dra Regiane Saturnino Ferreira) for the comments on the academic version of this paper presented to the Programa de Pós-Graduação em Zoologia of the Universidade Federal do Pará / Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi.
